tasks.title: Learn Windows API basics
tasks.details:
## Overview
Core APIs to master: CreateProcess (spawn processes), VirtualAlloc/VirtualAllocEx (allocate memory), WriteProcessMemory (write to other processes), OpenProcess (get handle to process), CreateRemoteThread (run code in other process). Study MSDN docs. Practice: write C program that allocates memory, writes bytes, executes. Use Visual Studio or mingw-w64.

### Implementation
Follow the implementation steps in the task description. Start with a minimal working version, then iterate.

### Key Concepts
- Understand the core algorithm before coding
- Handle edge cases explicitly
- Test against reference implementations
- Profile for performance bottlenecks

### Practice
- [ ] Implement from scratch without references
- [ ] Test with edge cases
- [ ] Compare output with established libraries
- [ ] Optimize for production use

### Completion Criteria
- [ ] Code produces correct output
- [ ] Can explain the implementation to others
- [ ] Edge cases handled properly
- [ ] Performance is acceptable

tasks.title: Understand PE file format
tasks.details:
## Overview
PE = Portable Executable (Windows .exe/.dll format). Key sections: DOS header, PE header, sections (.text=code, .data=data, .rdata=imports/exports). Import Address Table (IAT) = list of DLL functions used. Study with PE-bear or CFF Explorer. Why it matters: loaders parse PE, packers modify PE, AV scans PE. Resource: corkami.github.io/pics/

tasks.title: Study how AV/EDR detection works
tasks.details:
## Overview
Detection layers: 1) Signature - hash/pattern matching on disk, 2) Heuristics - suspicious API sequences, 3) Behavioral - runtime monitoring of actions, 4) Userland hooks - intercept API calls via ntdll.dll patching, 5) Kernel callbacks - OS notifies EDR of events, 6) ETW - Event Tracing for Windows telemetry. Understand each to bypass each.

tasks.title: Implement process hollowing
tasks.details:
## Overview
Steps: 1) CreateProcess with CREATE_SUSPENDED, 2) NtUnmapViewOfSection to hollow out the legitimate exe, 3) VirtualAllocEx at image base, 4) Write your PE headers and sections, 5) Set thread context to your entry point, 6) ResumeThread. Result: your code runs disguised as legitimate process. More evasive than injection. Reference: github.com/m0n0ph1/Process-Hollowing

tasks.title: Understand NTLM authentication
tasks.details:
## Overview
Challenge-response: 1) Client sends username, 2) Server sends 16-byte challenge, 3) Client encrypts challenge with password hash (NTLMv2: HMAC-MD5), sends response, 4) Server verifies against DC. Vulnerabilities: relay (forward auth to another service), pass-the-hash (use hash directly without password). When used: legacy systems, fallback when Kerberos fails, cross-forest.

tasks.title: Implement AES encryption with key derivation
tasks.details:
## Overview
Stronger than XOR. Use AES-256-CBC or AES-256-GCM. Key derivation: don't hardcode key directly. Options: derive from environment (hostname, username), fetch from C2, or use PBKDF2 from compile-time secret. Libraries: Windows CryptoAPI (BCrypt*), or compile OpenSSL statically. Decrypt payload in memory, never write decrypted to disk.

tasks.title: Learn direct syscalls
tasks.details:
## Overview
User API calls: your code → kernel32.dll → ntdll.dll → syscall instruction → kernel. EDR hooks ntdll.dll. Direct syscalls skip ntdll: your code → syscall instruction directly. Tools: SysWhispers (generates syscall stubs), HellsGate (dynamically resolves syscall numbers). Implement NtAllocateVirtualMemory, NtWriteVirtualMemory, NtCreateThreadEx via direct syscalls.

tasks.title: Implement ntdll unhooking
tasks.details:
## Overview
EDR modifies ntdll.dll in memory (hooks). Fix: 1) Read clean ntdll.dll from disk (C:\Windows\System32\ntdll.dll), 2) Map into memory, 3) Find .text section, 4) Copy clean bytes over hooked bytes. Result: API calls go to original code, bypassing EDR. Alternative: load ntdll from suspended process (also clean). Test: check if functions start with "mov r10, rcx; mov eax, SSN" (clean) or "jmp" (hooked).

### Implementation

tasks.title: Add delayed execution
tasks.details:
## Overview
Sandboxes have limited runtime (30s-5min). Simple evasion: Sleep(300000) - 5 minutes. But: sandboxes can fast-forward sleep. Better: check system uptime (sandbox just booted), check for user interaction (mouse/keyboard), check number of processes, check RAM size (<4GB = likely sandbox), check for VM artifacts. Combine multiple checks.

tasks.title: Execute Kerberoasting manually
tasks.details:
## Overview
Attack: any domain user can request service ticket for any SPN. Ticket is encrypted with service account's password hash. Offline crack = service account password. tasks.details:
## Overview
Direct syscalls: "syscall" instruction in your binary = detection. Indirect: find "syscall; ret" gadget in ntdll.dll, jump to it instead. Steps: 1) Find syscall number (SSN) for NtAllocateVirtualMemory, 2) Set up registers (rcx, rdx, r8, r9, stack), 3) Jump to syscall gadget in ntdll. Tools: HellsGate (resolve SSN at runtime). More evasive than direct syscalls.

tasks.title: Implement module stomping
tasks.details:
## Overview
Problem: allocated RWX memory is suspicious. Solution: overwrite a legitimate DLL in memory. Steps: 1) LoadLibrary a signed DLL you don't need (e.g., amsi.dll, clrjit.dll), 2) Change protection to RW, 3) Write your shellcode over .text section, 4) Change back to RX, 5) Execute. Your code now lives in "legitimate" DLL memory region. Harder for EDR to flag.

tasks.title: Add sleep obfuscation
tasks.details:
## Overview
Problem: beacon in memory during 60s sleep = scannable. Solution: encrypt entire beacon memory before sleep, decrypt after. Implementation: 1) Register VEH handler, 2) Encrypt beacon with key, 3) Sleep, 4) VEH triggers on first instruction (guard page or timer), 5) Decrypt beacon, continue. Techniques: Ekko, Foliage, Gargoyle. Advanced: use hardware breakpoints, CONTEXT manipulation.

tasks.title: Patch ETW in loader
tasks.details:
## Overview
ETW sends telemetry to EDR. Bypass: patch EtwEventWrite in ntdll.dll to return immediately. Code: void* addr = GetProcAddress(GetModuleHandle("ntdll"), "EtwEventWrite"); DWORD old; VirtualProtect(addr, 1, PAGE_READWRITE, &old); *(char*)addr = 0xC3; // ret. Do this early in loader. Also consider: NtTraceEvent, EtwEventWriteFull. Blinds many ETW-based detections.

### Implementation
Follow the implementation steps in the task description. Start with a minimal working version, then iterate.

tasks.details:
## Overview
Deploy DVWA, WebGoat, and Juice Shop locally with Docker. These provide safe, legal targets for practicing web attacks.

### Implementation
Follow the implementation steps in the task description. Start with a minimal working version, then iterate.

### Key Concepts
- Understand the core algorithm before coding
- Handle edge cases explicitly
- Test against reference implementations
- Profile for performance bottlenecks

### Practice
- [ ] Implement from scratch without references
- [ ] Test with edge cases
- [ ] Compare output with established libraries
- [ ] Optimize for production use

### Completion Criteria
- [ ] Code produces correct output
- [ ] Can explain the implementation to others
- [ ] Edge cases handled properly
- [ ] Performance is acceptable

### Implementation
Follow the implementation steps in the task description. Start with a minimal working version, then iterate.

### Key Concepts
- Understand the core algorithm before coding
- Handle edge cases explicitly
- Test against reference implementations
- Profile for performance bottlenecks

### Practice
- [ ] Implement from scratch without references
- [ ] Test with edge cases
- [ ] Compare output with established libraries
- [ ] Optimize for production use

### Completion Criteria
- [ ] Code produces correct output
- [ ] Can explain the implementation to others
- [ ] Edge cases handled properly
- [ ] Performance is acceptable
